text: Hi everyone,

You are on English Online, 
the Business English series.

Today we are following on with our second tip for 
building resilience, so let’s jump straight in.

Tip number two is about using different writing 
techniques to gain a more objective perspective.

This might sound like a 
strange one, but bear with me.

I was never someone who was into keeping diaries 
or writing journals or anything like that, but

even I have clearly seen some benefits of applying 
writing techniques into my day-to-day life.
As humans, we tend to have this ability

to over-exaggerate everything, and make 
everything seem way worse than it actually is.

This is true for both positive 
and negative situations.

When encountering a negative situation, by taking 
a couple of minutes to write down what happened,

and I mean what actually happened, some facts and 
some bullet points, it allows us to remove our

emotions that may have clouded our judgement and 
it allows us to gain a more objective perspective.

This morning’s meeting was an 
absolute mess. We were late

starting. The presentation really didn’t 
go down well. Felt like an absolute idiot,

how embarrassing. I think that we need to make 
lots of improvements. He seemed super unimpressed.

That meeting did not go well, okay, 
so. Meeting was at 10am. We were

meeting to discuss the contract. Negative 
aspects, negative aspects and positives,

well, I felt like I didn’t speak very well. 
 
Taking a minute to jot down ten bullet points

will take less than 10 minutes, so next time 
you encounter a difficult situation, try this:

Write down four facts and 
figures from the situation,

three positives and three negative outcomes 
and make sure that you are objective.

We can also look at our reaction and 
if there’s anything that we would’ve

changed or done differently. This helps 
us to be more prepared for the next time

that we encounter a similar situation and 
teaches us to take things less personally.

Alternatively, you may be somebody who 
writes down or jots down any of the little

things that is annoying them, frustrating 
them or getting them down. By doing this,

you can also practise the art of letting go by 
burning the sheet of paper with all of these

annoyances or ripping it up, blowing it away and 
letting go of all of your stress and worries.

If you can think of any other writing techniques 
that you have benefitted from to help build

resilience and lower your stress level then 
please share them in the comments below.
